eventTitle: The planet Earth forms from the accretion disc revolving around the young Sun with organic compounds (complex organic molecules) necessary for life having perhaps formed in the protoplanetary disk of cosmic dust grains surrounding it before the formation of the Earth.[13]
eventText: The planet Earth forms from the accretion disc revolving around the young Sun with organic compounds (complex organic molecules) necessary for life having perhaps formed in the protoplanetary disk of cosmic dust grains surrounding it before the formation of the Earth.[13]

eventTitle: According to the giant impact hypothesis; the Moon was formed when the planet Earth and the hypothesized planet Theia collided; sending a very large number of moonlets into orbit around the young Earth which eventually coalesced to form the Moon.[14] The gravitational pull of the new Moon stabilised the Earth's fluctuating axis of rotation and set up the conditions in which abiogenesis occurred.[15]
eventText: According to the giant impact hypothesis; the Moon was formed when the planet Earth and the hypothesized planet Theia collided; sending a very large number of moonlets into orbit around the young Earth which eventually coalesced to form the Moon.[14] The gravitational pull of the new Moon stabilised the Earth's fluctuating axis of rotation and set up the conditions in which abiogenesis occurred.[15]

eventTitle: First appearance of liquid water on Earth.
eventText: First appearance of liquid water on Earth.

eventTitle: Earliest possible appearance of life on Earth.[16][17][18][19]
eventText: Earliest possible appearance of life on Earth.[16][17][18][19]

eventTitle: Formation of a greenstone belt of the Acasta Gneiss of the Slave craton in Northwest Territories; Canada; the oldest rock belt in the world.[20]
eventText: Formation of a greenstone belt of the Acasta Gneiss of the Slave craton in Northwest Territories; Canada; the oldest rock belt in the world.[20]

eventTitle: "Late Heavy Bombardment (LHB): extended barrage of impact events upon the inner planets by meteoroids. Thermal flux from widespread hydrothermal activity during the LHB may have been conducive to abiogenesis and life's early diversification.[21] ""Remains of biotic life"" were found in 4.1 billion-year-old rocks in Western Australia.[22][23] This is when life most likely arose."
eventText: "Late Heavy Bombardment (LHB): extended barrage of impact events upon the inner planets by meteoroids. Thermal flux from widespread hydrothermal activity during the LHB may have been conducive to abiogenesis and life's early diversification.[21] ""Remains of biotic life"" were found in 4.1 billion-year-old rocks in Western Australia.[22][23] This is when life most likely arose."

eventTitle: Formation of a greenstone belt of the Isua complex of the western Greenland region; whose rocks show an isotope frequency suggestive of the presence of life.[20] The earliest evidences for life on Earth are 3.8 billion-year-old biogenic hematite in a banded iron formation of the Nuvvuagittuq Greenstone Belt in Canada;[27] graphite in 3.7 billion-year-old metasedimentary rocks discovered in western Greenland[28] and microbial mat fossils found in 3.48 billion-year-old sandstone discovered in Western Australia.[29][30]
eventText: Formation of a greenstone belt of the Isua complex of the western Greenland region; whose rocks show an isotope frequency suggestive of the presence of life.[20] The earliest evidences for life on Earth are 3.8 billion-year-old biogenic hematite in a banded iron formation of the Nuvvuagittuq Greenstone Belt in Canada;[27] graphite in 3.7 billion-year-old metasedimentary rocks discovered in western Greenland[28] and microbial mat fossils found in 3.48 billion-year-old sandstone discovered in Western Australia.[29][30]

eventTitle: Lifetime of the last universal common ancestor (LUCA);[31][32] the split between bacteria and archaea occurs.[33] Bacteria develop primitive forms of photosynthesis which at first did not produce oxygen.[34] These organisms generated Adenosine triphosphate (ATP) by exploiting a proton gradient; a mechanism still used in virtually all organisms.[35]
eventText: Lifetime of the last universal common ancestor (LUCA);[31][32] the split between bacteria and archaea occurs.[33] Bacteria develop primitive forms of photosynthesis which at first did not produce oxygen.[34] These organisms generated Adenosine triphosphate (ATP) by exploiting a proton gradient; a mechanism still used in virtually all organisms.[35]

eventTitle: Diversification and expansion of acritarchs.[36]
eventText: Diversification and expansion of acritarchs.[36]

eventTitle: Cells resembling prokaryotes appear.[24] These first organisms are chemoautotrophs: they use carbon dioxide as a carbon source and oxidize inorganic materials to extract energy. Later; prokaryotes evolve glycolysis; a set of chemical reactions that free the energy of organic molecules such as glucose and store it in the chemical bonds of ATP. Glycolysis (and ATP) continue to be used in almost all organisms; unchanged; to this day.[25][26]
eventText: Cells resembling prokaryotes appear.[24] These first organisms are chemoautotrophs: they use carbon dioxide as a carbon source and oxidize inorganic materials to extract energy. Later; prokaryotes evolve glycolysis; a set of chemical reactions that free the energy of organic molecules such as glucose and store it in the chemical bonds of ATP. Glycolysis (and ATP) continue to be used in almost all organisms; unchanged; to this day.[25][26]

eventTitle: Photosynthesizing cyanobacteria evolved; they used water as a reducing agent; thereby producing oxygen as a waste product.[37] The oxygen initially oxidizes dissolved iron in the oceans; creating iron ore. The oxygen concentration in the atmosphere slowly rose; acting as a poison for many bacteria and eventually triggering the Great Oxygenation Event. The Moon; still very close to Earth; caused tides 1;000 feet (305Â m) high.[citation needed] The Earth was continually wracked by hurricane-force winds. These extreme mixing influences are thought to have stimulated evolutionary processes.[citation needed]
eventText: Photosynthesizing cyanobacteria evolved; they used water as a reducing agent; thereby producing oxygen as a waste product.[37] The oxygen initially oxidizes dissolved iron in the oceans; creating iron ore. The oxygen concentration in the atmosphere slowly rose; acting as a poison for many bacteria and eventually triggering the Great Oxygenation Event. The Moon; still very close to Earth; caused tides 1;000 feet (305Â m) high.[citation needed] The Earth was continually wracked by hurricane-force winds. These extreme mixing influences are thought to have stimulated evolutionary processes.[citation needed]

eventTitle: Oldest evidence for microbial life on land in the form of organic matter-rich paleosols; ephemeral ponds and alluvial sequences; some of them bearing microfossils.[38]
eventText: Oldest evidence for microbial life on land in the form of organic matter-rich paleosols; ephemeral ponds and alluvial sequences; some of them bearing microfossils.[38]

eventTitle: Great Oxygenation Event led by cyanobacteria's oxygenic photosynthesis.[37] Commencement of plate tectonics with old marine crust dense enough to subduct.[20]
eventText: Great Oxygenation Event led by cyanobacteria's oxygenic photosynthesis.[37] Commencement of plate tectonics with old marine crust dense enough to subduct.[20]

eventTitle: Eukaryotic cells appear. Eukaryotes contain membrane-bound organelles with diverse functions; probably derived from prokaryotes engulfing each other via phagocytosis. (See Symbiogenesis and Endosymbiont). Bacterial viruses (bacteriophage) emerge before; or soon after; the divergence of the prokaryotic and eukaryotic lineages.[39] The appearance of red beds show that an oxidising atmosphere had been produced. Incentives now favoured the spread of eukaryotic life.[40][41][42]
eventText: Eukaryotic cells appear. Eukaryotes contain membrane-bound organelles with diverse functions; probably derived from prokaryotes engulfing each other via phagocytosis. (See Symbiogenesis and Endosymbiont). Bacterial viruses (bacteriophage) emerge before; or soon after; the divergence of the prokaryotic and eukaryotic lineages.[39] The appearance of red beds show that an oxidising atmosphere had been produced. Incentives now favoured the spread of eukaryotic life.[40][41][42]

eventTitle: Great increase in stromatolite diversity.
eventText: Great increase in stromatolite diversity.

eventTitle: Earliest land fungi[43]
eventText: Earliest land fungi[43]

eventTitle: Meiosis and sexual reproduction are present in single-celled eukaryotes; and possibly in the common ancestor of all eukaryotes.[44] Sex may even have arisen earlier in the RNA world.[45] Sexual reproduction first appears in the fossil records; it may have increased the rate of evolution.[46]
eventText: Meiosis and sexual reproduction are present in single-celled eukaryotes; and possibly in the common ancestor of all eukaryotes.[44] Sex may even have arisen earlier in the RNA world.[45] Sexual reproduction first appears in the fossil records; it may have increased the rate of evolution.[46]

eventTitle: The first non-marine eukaryotes move onto land. They were photosynthetic and multicellular; indicating that plants evolved much earlier than originally thought.[47]
eventText: The first non-marine eukaryotes move onto land. They were photosynthetic and multicellular; indicating that plants evolved much earlier than originally thought.[47]

eventTitle: First protozoa (ex: Melanocyrillium)
eventText: First protozoa (ex: Melanocyrillium)

eventTitle: A global glaciation may have occurred.[48][49] Opinion is divided on whether it increased or decreased biodiversity or the rate of evolution.[50][51][52] It is believed that this was due to evolution of the first land plants; which increased the amount of oxygen and lowered the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere.[53]
eventText: A global glaciation may have occurred.[48][49] Opinion is divided on whether it increased or decreased biodiversity or the rate of evolution.[50][51][52] It is believed that this was due to evolution of the first land plants; which increased the amount of oxygen and lowered the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere.[53]

eventTitle: The accumulation of atmospheric oxygen allows the formation of an ozone layer.[54] Prior to this; land-based life would probably have required other chemicals to attenuate ultraviolet radiation enough to permit colonisation of the land.[38]
eventText: The accumulation of atmospheric oxygen allows the formation of an ozone layer.[54] Prior to this; land-based life would probably have required other chemicals to attenuate ultraviolet radiation enough to permit colonisation of the land.[38]

eventTitle: The Ediacara biota represent the first large; complex aquatic multicellular organisms â although their affinities remain a subject of debate.[55]
eventText: The Ediacara biota represent the first large; complex aquatic multicellular organisms â although their affinities remain a subject of debate.[55]

eventTitle: First fossil evidence for Ctenophora (comb jellies); Porifera (sponges); Anthozoa (corals and sea anemones)
eventText: First fossil evidence for Ctenophora (comb jellies); Porifera (sponges); Anthozoa (corals and sea anemones)

eventTitle: Most modern phyla of animals begin to appear in the fossil record during the Cambrian explosion.[56][57]
eventText: Most modern phyla of animals begin to appear in the fossil record during the Cambrian explosion.[56][57]

eventTitle: Major diversification of living things in the oceans: chordates; arthropods (e.g. trilobites; crustaceans); echinoderms; molluscs; brachiopods; foraminifers and radiolarians; etc.
eventText: Major diversification of living things in the oceans: chordates; arthropods (e.g. trilobites; crustaceans); echinoderms; molluscs; brachiopods; foraminifers and radiolarians; etc.

eventTitle: The first known footprints on land date to 530 Ma.[61]
eventText: The first known footprints on land date to 530 Ma.[61]

eventText: Earliest graptolites

eventTitle: Earliest crustaceans
eventText: Earliest crustaceans

eventTitle: First cephalopods (nautiloids) and chitons
eventText: First cephalopods (nautiloids) and chitons

eventTitle: Fossilization of the Burgess Shale
eventText: Fossilization of the Burgess Shale

eventTitle: Jellyfish have existed since at least this time.
eventText: Jellyfish have existed since at least this time.

eventTitle: First vertebrates with true bones (jawless fishes)
eventText: First vertebrates with true bones (jawless fishes)

eventTitle: First complete conodonts and echinoids appear
eventText: First complete conodonts and echinoids appear

eventTitle: First agnathan fishes: Heterostraci; Galeaspida; and Pituriaspida
eventText: First agnathan fishes: Heterostraci; Galeaspida; and Pituriaspida

eventTitle: Earliest ray-finned fishes; trigonotarbid arachnids; and land scorpions[62]
eventText: Earliest ray-finned fishes; trigonotarbid arachnids; and land scorpions[62]

eventTitle: First signs of teeth in fish. Earliest Nautilida; lycophytes; and trimerophytes.
eventText: First signs of teeth in fish. Earliest Nautilida; lycophytes; and trimerophytes.

eventTitle: First lichens; stoneworts. Earliest harvestmen; mites; hexapods (springtails) and ammonoids. The first known tetrapod tracks on land.
eventText: First lichens; stoneworts. Earliest harvestmen; mites; hexapods (springtails) and ammonoids. The first known tetrapod tracks on land.

eventTitle: Acanthostega is one of the earliest vertebrates capable of walking.
eventText: Acanthostega is one of the earliest vertebrates capable of walking.

eventTitle: By the start of the Carboniferous Period; the Earth begins to resemble its present state. Insects roamed the land and would soon take to the skies; sharks swam the oceans as top predators;[63] and vegetation covered the land; with seed-bearing plants and forests soon to flourish. Four-limbed tetrapods gradually gain adaptations which will help them occupy a terrestrial life-habit.
eventText: By the start of the Carboniferous Period; the Earth begins to resemble its present state. Insects roamed the land and would soon take to the skies; sharks swam the oceans as top predators;[63] and vegetation covered the land; with seed-bearing plants and forests soon to flourish. Four-limbed tetrapods gradually gain adaptations which will help them occupy a terrestrial life-habit.

eventTitle: First crabs and ferns. Land flora dominated by seed ferns. The Xinhang forest grows around this time[64]
eventText: First crabs and ferns. Land flora dominated by seed ferns. The Xinhang forest grows around this time[64]

eventTitle: First large sharks; ratfishes; and hagfish
eventText: First large sharks; ratfishes; and hagfish

eventTitle: Diversification of amphibians
eventText: Diversification of amphibians

eventTitle: First amniote vertebrates (Paleothyris)
eventText: First amniote vertebrates (Paleothyris)

eventTitle: Synapsids (precursors to mammals) separate from sauropsids (reptiles) in late Carboniferous.[65]
eventText: Synapsids (precursors to mammals) separate from sauropsids (reptiles) in late Carboniferous.[65]

eventTitle: Earliest diapsid reptiles (e.g. Petrolacosaurus)
eventText: Earliest diapsid reptiles (e.g. Petrolacosaurus)

eventTitle: Earliest known octopus (Pohlsepia)
eventText: Earliest known octopus (Pohlsepia)

eventTitle: Earliest beetles; seed plants and conifers diversify while lepidodendrids and sphenopsids decrease. Terrestrial temnospondyl amphibians and pelycosaurs (e.g. Dimetrodon) diversify in species.
eventText: Earliest beetles; seed plants and conifers diversify while lepidodendrids and sphenopsids decrease. Terrestrial temnospondyl amphibians and pelycosaurs (e.g. Dimetrodon) diversify in species.

eventTitle: Therapsid synapsids separate from pelycosaur synapsids
eventText: Therapsid synapsids separate from pelycosaur synapsids

eventTitle: Gorgonopsians appear in the fossil record
eventText: Gorgonopsians appear in the fossil record

eventTitle: "The PermianâTriassic extinction event eliminates over 90-95% of marine species. Terrestrial organisms were not as seriously affected as the marine biota. This ""clearing of the slate"" may have led to an ensuing diversification; but life on land took 30 million years to completely recover.[66]"
eventText: "The PermianâTriassic extinction event eliminates over 90-95% of marine species. Terrestrial organisms were not as seriously affected as the marine biota. This ""clearing of the slate"" may have led to an ensuing diversification; but life on land took 30 million years to completely recover.[66]"

eventTitle: Triadobatrachus massinoti is the earliest known frog
eventText: Triadobatrachus massinoti is the earliest known frog

eventTitle: "The Mesozoic Marine Revolution begins: increasingly well adapted and diverse predators[who?] pressurize sessile marine groups; the ""balance of power"" in the oceans shifts dramatically as some groups of prey[who?] adapt more rapidly and effectively than others[who?]."
eventText: "The Mesozoic Marine Revolution begins: increasingly well adapted and diverse predators[who?] pressurize sessile marine groups; the ""balance of power"" in the oceans shifts dramatically as some groups of prey[who?] adapt more rapidly and effectively than others[who?]."

eventTitle: Sturgeon and paddlefish (Acipenseridae) first appear.
eventText: Sturgeon and paddlefish (Acipenseridae) first appear.

eventTitle: Earliest ichthyosaurs
eventText: Earliest ichthyosaurs

eventTitle: Increase in diversity of gomphodont cynodonts and rhynchosaurs
eventText: Increase in diversity of gomphodont cynodonts and rhynchosaurs

eventTitle: Earliest dinosaurs (prosauropods); first cardiid bivalves; diversity in cycads; bennettitaleans; and conifers. First teleost fishes. First mammals (Adelobasileus).
eventText: Earliest dinosaurs (prosauropods); first cardiid bivalves; diversity in cycads; bennettitaleans; and conifers. First teleost fishes. First mammals (Adelobasileus).

eventTitle: Seed-producing Gymnosperm forests dominate the land; herbivores grow to huge sizes to accommodate the large guts necessary to digest the nutrient-poor plants.[citation needed] First flies and turtles (Odontochelys). First coelophysoid dinosaurs.
eventText: Seed-producing Gymnosperm forests dominate the land; herbivores grow to huge sizes to accommodate the large guts necessary to digest the nutrient-poor plants.[citation needed] First flies and turtles (Odontochelys). First coelophysoid dinosaurs.

eventTitle: The Massive extinction of Triassic/Jurassic; that wiped out most of the group of pseudosuchians and gave the opportunity of dinosaurs including the Apatosaurus; Tyrannosaurus; Perrotasaurus; and Stegosaurus to enter their golden age.
eventText: The Massive extinction of Triassic/Jurassic; that wiped out most of the group of pseudosuchians and gave the opportunity of dinosaurs including the Apatosaurus; Tyrannosaurus; Perrotasaurus; and Stegosaurus to enter their golden age.

eventTitle: "The first accepted evidence for viruses that infect eukaryotic cells (at least; the group Geminiviridae) existed.[67] Viruses are still poorly understood and may have arisen before ""life"" itself; or may be a more recent phenomenon. Major extinctions in terrestrial vertebrates and large amphibians. Earliest examples of armoured dinosaurs"
eventText: "The first accepted evidence for viruses that infect eukaryotic cells (at least; the group Geminiviridae) existed.[67] Viruses are still poorly understood and may have arisen before ""life"" itself; or may be a more recent phenomenon. Major extinctions in terrestrial vertebrates and large amphibians. Earliest examples of armoured dinosaurs"

eventTitle: First pterosaurs with specialized feeding (Dorygnathus). First sauropod dinosaurs. Diversification in small; ornithischian dinosaurs: heterodontosaurids; fabrosaurids; and scelidosaurids.
eventText: First pterosaurs with specialized feeding (Dorygnathus). First sauropod dinosaurs. Diversification in small; ornithischian dinosaurs: heterodontosaurids; fabrosaurids; and scelidosaurids.

eventTitle: Pliosauroids appear in the fossil record. First lepidopteran insects (Archaeolepis); hermit crabs; modern starfish; irregular echinoids; corbulid bivalves; and tubulipore bryozoans. Extensive development of sponge reefs.
eventText: Pliosauroids appear in the fossil record. First lepidopteran insects (Archaeolepis); hermit crabs; modern starfish; irregular echinoids; corbulid bivalves; and tubulipore bryozoans. Extensive development of sponge reefs.

eventTitle: First members of the Stegosauria group of dinosaurs
eventText: First members of the Stegosauria group of dinosaurs

eventTitle: Earliest salamanders; newts; cryptoclidids; elasmosaurid plesiosaurs; and cladotherian mammals. Sauropod dinosaurs diversify.
eventText: Earliest salamanders; newts; cryptoclidids; elasmosaurid plesiosaurs; and cladotherian mammals. Sauropod dinosaurs diversify.

eventTitle: First rays and glycymeridid bivalves. First vampire squids[68]
eventText: First rays and glycymeridid bivalves. First vampire squids[68]

eventTitle: Pterodactyloid pterosaurs first appear[69]
eventText: Pterodactyloid pterosaurs first appear[69]

eventTitle: Ceratopsian dinosaurs appear in the fossil record (Yinlong) and the oldest known Eutherian Mammal appear in the fossil record: Juramaia.
eventText: Ceratopsian dinosaurs appear in the fossil record (Yinlong) and the oldest known Eutherian Mammal appear in the fossil record: Juramaia.

eventTitle: Multituberculate mammals (genus Rugosodon) appear in eastern China
eventText: Multituberculate mammals (genus Rugosodon) appear in eastern China

eventTitle: First blood-sucking insects (ceratopogonids); rudist bivalves; and cheilostome bryozoans. Archaeopteryx; a possible ancestor to the birds; appears in the fossil record; along with triconodontid and symmetrodont mammals. Diversity in stegosaurian and theropod dinosaurs.
eventText: First blood-sucking insects (ceratopogonids); rudist bivalves; and cheilostome bryozoans. Archaeopteryx; a possible ancestor to the birds; appears in the fossil record; along with triconodontid and symmetrodont mammals. Diversity in stegosaurian and theropod dinosaurs.

eventTitle: Orb-weaver spiders appear
eventText: Orb-weaver spiders appear

eventTitle: The rise of the angiosperms: Some of these flowering plants bear structures that attract insects and other animals to spread pollen; other angiosperms were pollinated by wind or water. This innovation causes a major burst of animal evolution through coevolution. First freshwater pelomedusid turtles. Earliest krill.
eventText: The rise of the angiosperms: Some of these flowering plants bear structures that attract insects and other animals to spread pollen; other angiosperms were pollinated by wind or water. This innovation causes a major burst of animal evolution through coevolution. First freshwater pelomedusid turtles. Earliest krill.

eventTitle: Oldest fossils of heterokonts; including both marine diatoms and silicoflagellates
eventText: Oldest fossils of heterokonts; including both marine diatoms and silicoflagellates

eventText: First monotreme mammals

eventTitle: Xiphactinus; a large predatory fish; appears in the fossil record
eventText: Xiphactinus; a large predatory fish; appears in the fossil record

eventTitle: First hesperornithes; toothed diving birds. Earliest limopsid; verticordiid; and thyasirid bivalves.
eventText: First hesperornithes; toothed diving birds. Earliest limopsid; verticordiid; and thyasirid bivalves.

eventTitle: Spinosaurus; the largest theropod dinosaur; appears in the fossil record
eventText: Spinosaurus; the largest theropod dinosaur; appears in the fossil record

eventTitle: Earliest bees

eventTitle: First crocodilians evolve
eventText: First crocodilians evolve

eventTitle: Extinction of ichthyosaurs. Earliest snakes and nuculanid bivalves. Large diversification in angiosperms: magnoliids; rosids; hamamelidids; monocots; and ginger. Earliest examples of ticks. Probable origins of placental mammals (earliest undisputed fossil evidence is 66 Ma).
eventText: Extinction of ichthyosaurs. Earliest snakes and nuculanid bivalves. Large diversification in angiosperms: magnoliids; rosids; hamamelidids; monocots; and ginger. Earliest examples of ticks. Probable origins of placental mammals (earliest undisputed fossil evidence is 66 Ma).

eventTitle: First ants
eventText: First ants

eventTitle: Multituberculate mammals increase in diversity. First yoldiid bivalves.
eventText: Multituberculate mammals increase in diversity. First yoldiid bivalves.

eventTitle: Tyrannosaurus; the largest terrestrial predator of what is now western North America appears in the fossil record. First species of Triceratops.
eventText: Tyrannosaurus; the largest terrestrial predator of what is now western North America appears in the fossil record. First species of Triceratops.

eventTitle: Rapid dominance of conifers and ginkgos in high latitudes; along with mammals becoming the dominant species. First psammobiid bivalves. Earliest rodents. Rapid diversification in ants.
eventText: Rapid dominance of conifers and ginkgos in high latitudes; along with mammals becoming the dominant species. First psammobiid bivalves. Earliest rodents. Rapid diversification in ants.

eventTitle: The CretaceousâPaleogene extinction event eradicates about half of all animal species; including mosasaurs; pterosaurs; plesiosaurs; ammonites; belemnites; rudist and inoceramid bivalves; most planktic foraminifers; and all of the dinosaurs excluding the birds.[70]
eventText: The CretaceousâPaleogene extinction event eradicates about half of all animal species; including mosasaurs; pterosaurs; plesiosaurs; ammonites; belemnites; rudist and inoceramid bivalves; most planktic foraminifers; and all of the dinosaurs excluding the birds.[70]

eventTitle: Evolution of the creodonts; an important group of meat-eating (carnivorous) mammals
eventText: Evolution of the creodonts; an important group of meat-eating (carnivorous) mammals

eventTitle: Evolution of the first penguins
eventText: Evolution of the first penguins

eventTitle: Diversification of large; flightless birds. Earliest true primates;[who?] along with the first semelid bivalves; edentate; carnivoran and lipotyphlan mammals; and owls. The ancestors of the carnivorous mammals (miacids) were alive.[citation needed]
eventText: Diversification of large; flightless birds. Earliest true primates;[who?] along with the first semelid bivalves; edentate; carnivoran and lipotyphlan mammals; and owls. The ancestors of the carnivorous mammals (miacids) were alive.[citation needed]

eventTitle: Earliest sailfish appear
eventText: Earliest sailfish appear

eventTitle: Gastornis; a large flightless bird; appears in the fossil record
eventText: Gastornis; a large flightless bird; appears in the fossil record

eventTitle: Modern bird groups diversify (first song birds; parrots; loons; swifts; woodpeckers); first whale (Himalayacetus); earliest lagomorphs; armadillos; appearance of sirenian; proboscidean; perissodactyl and artiodactyl mammals in the fossil record. Angiosperms diversify. The ancestor (according to theory) of the species in the genus Carcharodon; the early mako shark Isurus hastalis; is alive.
eventText: Modern bird groups diversify (first song birds; parrots; loons; swifts; woodpeckers); first whale (Himalayacetus); earliest lagomorphs; armadillos; appearance of sirenian; proboscidean; perissodactyl and artiodactyl mammals in the fossil record. Angiosperms diversify. The ancestor (according to theory) of the species in the genus Carcharodon; the early mako shark Isurus hastalis; is alive.

eventTitle: First bats appear (Onychonycteris)
eventText: First bats appear (Onychonycteris)

eventTitle: Peak diversity of dinoflagellates and nannofossils; increase in diversity of anomalodesmatan and heteroconch bivalves; brontotheres; tapirs; rhinoceroses; and camels appear in the fossil record; diversification of primates
eventText: Peak diversity of dinoflagellates and nannofossils; increase in diversity of anomalodesmatan and heteroconch bivalves; brontotheres; tapirs; rhinoceroses; and camels appear in the fossil record; diversification of primates

eventTitle: Modern-type butterflies and moths appear. Extinction of Gastornis. Basilosaurus; one of the first of the giant whales; appeared in the fossil record.
eventText: Modern-type butterflies and moths appear. Extinction of Gastornis. Basilosaurus; one of the first of the giant whales; appeared in the fossil record.

eventTitle: Earliest bears
eventText: Earliest bears

eventTitle: "First nimravid (""false saber-toothed cats"") carnivores â these species are unrelated to modern-type felines. First alligators"
eventText: "First nimravid (""false saber-toothed cats"") carnivores â these species are unrelated to modern-type felines. First alligators"

eventTitle: Grasses diversify from among the monocot angiosperms; grasslands begin to expand. Slight increase in diversity of cold-tolerant ostracods and foraminifers; along with major extinctions of gastropods; reptiles; amphibians; and multituberculate mammals. Many modern mammal groups begin to appear: first glyptodonts; ground sloths; canids; peccaries; and the first eagles and hawks. Diversity in toothed and baleen whales.
eventText: Grasses diversify from among the monocot angiosperms; grasslands begin to expand. Slight increase in diversity of cold-tolerant ostracods and foraminifers; along with major extinctions of gastropods; reptiles; amphibians; and multituberculate mammals. Many modern mammal groups begin to appear: first glyptodonts; ground sloths; canids; peccaries; and the first eagles and hawks. Diversity in toothed and baleen whales.

eventTitle: Evolution of the thylacinid marsupials (Badjcinus)
eventText: Evolution of the thylacinid marsupials (Badjcinus)

eventTitle: First balanids and eucalypts; extinction of embrithopod and brontothere mammals; earliest pigs and cats
eventText: First balanids and eucalypts; extinction of embrithopod and brontothere mammals; earliest pigs and cats

eventTitle: Paraceratherium appears in the fossil record; the largest terrestrial mammal that ever lived. First pelicans.

eventTitle: The Great American Interchange; where various land and freshwater faunas migrated between North and South America. Armadillos; opossums; hummingbirds Phorusrhacids; Ground Sloths; Glyptodonts; and Meridiungulates traveled to North America; while horses; tapirs; saber-toothed cats; Jaguars; Bears; Coaties; Ferrets; Otters; Skunks and deer entered South America.

eventTitle: First tree sloths and hippopotami; diversification of grazing herbivores like zebras and elephants; large carnivorous mammals like lions and the genus Canis; burrowing rodents; kangaroos; birds; and small carnivores; vultures increase in size; decrease in the number of perissodactyl mammals. Extinction of nimravid carnivores. First leopard seals.

eventTitle: "If a failure of the Wilkes Subglacial Basin ""ice plug"" in the next few centuries were to endanger the East Antarctic Ice Sheet; it will take up to this long to melt completely. Sea levels would rise 3 to 4 metres.[7] One of the potential long-term effects of global warming; this is separate from the shorter-term threat of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet."
eventText: "If a failure of the Wilkes Subglacial Basin ""ice plug"" in the next few centuries were to endanger the East Antarctic Ice Sheet; it will take up to this long to melt completely. eventTitle: The red supergiant star Antares will likely have exploded in a supernova. The explosion is expected to be easily visible in daylight.[8]
eventText: The red supergiant star Antares will likely have exploded in a supernova. The explosion is expected to be easily visible in daylight.[8]

eventTitle: According to the Sahara pump theory; the precession of Earth's poles will move the North African Monsoon far enough north to convert the Sahara back into a tropical climate; as it was 5;000â10;000 years ago.[9][10]

eventTitle: The northern Martian polar ice cap could recede as Mars reaches a warming peak of the northern hemisphere during the c. 50;000-year perihelion precession aspect of its Milankovitch cycle.[11][12]

eventTitle: The small red dwarf Ross 248 will pass within 3.024 light-years of Earth; becoming the closest star to the Sun.[13] It will recede after about 8;000 years; making first Alpha Centauri again and then Gliese 445 the nearest stars[13] (see timeline).
eventText: The small red dwarf Ross 248 will pass within 3.024 light-years of Earth; becoming the closest star to the Sun.[13] It will recede after about 8;000 years; making first Alpha Centauri again and then Gliese 445 the nearest stars[13] (see timeline).

eventTitle: According to Berger and Loutre; the current interglacial period ends;[14] sending the Earth back into a glacial period of the current ice age; regardless of the effects of anthropogenic global warming. Niagara Falls will have eroded away the remaining 32Â km to Lake Erie; and cease to exist.[15] The many glacial lakes of the Canadian Shield will have been erased by post-glacial rebound and erosion.[16]
eventText: According to Berger and Loutre; the current interglacial period ends;[14] sending the Earth back into a glacial period of the current ice age; regardless of the effects of anthropogenic global warming. Niagara Falls will have eroded away the remaining 32Â km to Lake Erie; and cease to exist.[15] The many glacial lakes of the Canadian Shield will have been erased by post-glacial rebound and erosion.[16]

eventTitle: The length of the day used for astronomical timekeeping reaches about 86;401 SI seconds; due to lunar tides decelerating the Earth's rotation. Under the present-day timekeeping system; either a leap second would need to be added to the clock every single day; or else by then; in order to compensate; the length of the day would have had to have been officially lengthened by one SI second.[17]
eventText: The length of the day used for astronomical timekeeping reaches about 86;401 SI seconds; due to lunar tides decelerating the Earth's rotation. Under the present-day timekeeping system; either a leap second would need to be added to the clock every single day; or else by then; in order to compensate; the length of the day would have had to have been officially lengthened by one SI second.[17]

eventTitle: Native North American earthworms; such as Megascolecidae; will have naturally spread north through the United States Upper Midwest to the CanadaâUS border; recovering from the Laurentide Ice Sheet glaciation (38Â°N to 49Â°N); assuming a migration rate of 10Â metres per year.[21] (However; non-native invasive earthworms of North America have already been introduced by humans on a much shorter timescale; causing a shock to the regional ecosystem.)

eventTitle: The proper motion of stars across the celestial sphere; which is the result of their movement through the Milky Way; renders many of the constellations unrecognisable.[18]

eventTitle: "At some point in the next ""several"" hundred thousand years; the WolfâRayet star WR 104 is expected to explode in a supernova. It has been suggested that it may produce a gamma-ray burst that could pose a threat to life on Earth should its poles be aligned 12Â° or lower towards Earth. The star's axis of rotation has yet to be determined with certainty.[24]"

eventTitle: Earth will likely have been hit by an asteroid of roughly 1Â km in diameter; assuming it cannot be averted.[25]

eventTitle: The rugged terrain of Badlands National Park in South Dakota will have eroded away completely.[26]

eventTitle: Desdemona and Cressida; moons of Uranus; will likely have collided.[30]

eventTitle: Highest estimated time until the red supergiant star Betelgeuse explodes in a supernova. The explosion is expected to be easily visible in daylight.[28][29] It may explode in as little as 100;000 years; if particular evolutionary models turn out to be correct.
eventText: Highest estimated time until the red supergiant star Betelgeuse explodes in a supernova. The explosion is expected to be easily visible in daylight.[28][29] It may explode in as little as 100;000 years; if particular evolutionary models turn out to be correct.

eventTitle: 27% of the ocean's mass will have been subducted into the mantle. If this were to continue uninterrupted; it would reach an equilibrium where 65% of the surface water would remain at the surface.[68]
eventText: 27% of the ocean's mass will have been subducted into the mantle. If this were to continue uninterrupted; it would reach an equilibrium where 65% of the surface water would remain at the surface.[68]

eventTitle: "Meteor Crater; a large impact crater in Arizona considered the ""freshest"" of its kind; will have eroded away.[27]"
eventText: "Meteor Crater; a large impact crater in Arizona considered the ""freshest"" of its kind; will have eroded away.[27]"

eventTitle: Earth will likely have undergone a supervolcanic eruption large enough to erupt 3;200Â km3 (770 cubic miles) of magma; an event comparable to the Toba supereruption 75;000 years ago.[20]
eventText: Earth will likely have undergone a supervolcanic eruption large enough to erupt 3;200Â km3 (770 cubic miles) of magma; an event comparable to the Toba supereruption 75;000 years ago.[20]

eventTitle: "The Sun's luminosity has risen by 10%; causing Earth's surface temperatures to reach an average of c. 320Â K (47Â Â°C; 116Â Â°F). The atmosphere will become a ""moist greenhouse""; resulting in a runaway evaporation of the oceans.[63][69] This would cause plate tectonics to stop completely; if not already stopped before this time.[70] Pockets of water may still be present at the poles; allowing abodes for simple life.[71][72]"
eventText: "The Sun's luminosity has risen by 10%; causing Earth's surface temperatures to reach an average of c. 320Â K (47Â Â°C; 116Â Â°F). The atmosphere will become a ""moist greenhouse""; resulting in a runaway evaporation of the oceans.[63][69] This would cause plate tectonics to stop completely; if not already stopped before this time.[70] Pockets of water may still be present at the poles; allowing abodes for simple life.[71][72]"

eventTitle: High estimate till all plant life dies out assuming some form of photosynthesis is possible despite extremely low carbon dioxide levels. If this is possible; rising temperatures will make a complex biosphere unsustainable from this point on.[73][74][75]
eventText: High estimate till all plant life dies out assuming some form of photosynthesis is possible despite extremely low carbon dioxide levels. If this is possible; rising temperatures will make a complex biosphere unsustainable from this point on.[73][74][75]

eventTitle: Eukaryotic life dies out on Earth due to carbon dioxide starvation. Only prokaryotes remain.[67]
eventText: Eukaryotic life dies out on Earth due to carbon dioxide starvation. Only prokaryotes remain.[67]

eventTitle: The star Gliese 710 will pass as close as 9;000Â AU (0.14Â light-years to the Sun) before moving away. This will gravitationally perturb members of the Oort cloud; a halo of icy bodies orbiting at the edge of the Solar System; thereafter raising the likelihood of a cometary impact in the inner Solar System.[31]
eventText: The star Gliese 710 will pass as close as 9;000Â AU (0.14Â light-years to the Sun) before moving away. This will gravitationally perturb members of the Oort cloud; a halo of icy bodies orbiting at the edge of the Solar System; thereafter raising the likelihood of a cometary impact in the inner Solar System.[31]

eventTitle: The Sun's rising luminosity causes its circumstellar habitable zone to move outwards; as carbon dioxide rises in Mars's atmosphere; its surface temperature rises to levels akin to Earth during the ice age.[67][76]
eventText: The Sun's rising luminosity causes its circumstellar habitable zone to move outwards; as carbon dioxide rises in Mars's atmosphere; its surface temperature rises to levels akin to Earth during the ice age.[67][76]

eventTitle: Lower estimate until all prokaryotic life will go extinct.[67]
eventText: Lower estimate until all prokaryotic life will go extinct.[67]

eventTitle: The Grand Canyon will erode further; deepening slightly; but principally widening into a broad valley surrounding the Colorado River.[33]
eventText: The Grand Canyon will erode further; deepening slightly; but principally widening into a broad valley surrounding the Colorado River.[33]

eventTitle: High estimate until the Earth's oceans evaporate if the atmospheric pressure were to decrease via the nitrogen cycle.[77]
eventText: High estimate until the Earth's oceans evaporate if the atmospheric pressure were to decrease via the nitrogen cycle.[77]

eventTitle: Estimated time for the recovery of coral reef ecosystems from human-caused ocean acidification; a similar time was taken for the recovery of marine ecosystems after the acidification event that occurred about 65 million years ago.[32]
eventText: Estimated time for the recovery of coral reef ecosystems from human-caused ocean acidification; a similar time was taken for the recovery of marine ecosystems after the acidification event that occurred about 65 million years ago.[32]

eventTitle: The Earth's outer core freezes; if the inner core continues to grow at its current rate of 1Â mm (0.039Â in) per year.[78][79] Without its liquid outer core; the Earth's magnetic field shuts down;[80] and charged particles emanating from the Sun gradually deplete the atmosphere.[81]
eventText: The Earth's outer core freezes; if the inner core continues to grow at its current rate of 1Â mm (0.039Â in) per year.[78][79] Without its liquid outer core; the Earth's magnetic field shuts down;[80] and charged particles emanating from the Sun gradually deplete the atmosphere.[81]

eventTitle: The Sun will have reached a maximum surface temperature of 5;820 K. From then on; it will become gradually cooler while its luminosity will continue to increase.[69]
eventText: The Sun will have reached a maximum surface temperature of 5;820 K. From then on; it will become gradually cooler while its luminosity will continue to increase.[69]

eventTitle: Average orbital half-life of current centaurs; that are unstable because of gravitational interaction of the several outer planets.[34] See predictions for notable centaurs.
eventText: Average orbital half-life of current centaurs; that are unstable because of gravitational interaction of the several outer planets.[34] See predictions for notable centaurs.

eventTitle: Earth's surface temperature reaches c. 420Â K (147Â Â°C; 296Â Â°F); even at the poles. At this point; all life; now reduced to unicellular colonies in isolated; scattered microenvironments such as high-altitude lakes or caves; will go extinct.[63][82]
eventText: Earth's surface temperature reaches c. 420Â K (147Â Â°C; 296Â Â°F); even at the poles. At this point; all life; now reduced to unicellular colonies in isolated; scattered microenvironments such as high-altitude lakes or caves; will go extinct.[63][82]

eventTitle: Median point at which the Moon's rising distance from the Earth lessens its stabilising effect on the Earth's axial tilt. As a consequence; Earth's true polar wander becomes chaotic and extreme; leading to dramatic shifts in the planet's climate due to the changing axial tilt.[84]
eventText: Median point at which the Moon's rising distance from the Earth lessens its stabilising effect on the Earth's axial tilt. As a consequence; Earth's true polar wander becomes chaotic and extreme; leading to dramatic shifts in the planet's climate due to the changing axial tilt.[84]

eventTitle: There is a roughly 1-in-100;000 chance that the Earth might be ejected into interstellar space by a stellar encounter before this point; and a 1-in-3-million chance that it will then be captured by another star. Were this to happen; life; assuming it survived the interstellar journey; could potentially continue for far longer.[83]
eventText: There is a roughly 1-in-100;000 chance that the Earth might be ejected into interstellar space by a stellar encounter before this point; and a 1-in-3-million chance that it will then be captured by another star. Were this to happen; life; assuming it survived the interstellar journey; could potentially continue for far longer.[83]

eventTitle: 1% chance that Jupiter's gravity may make Mercury's orbit so eccentric as to collide with Venus; sending the inner Solar System into chaos. Possible scenarios include Mercury colliding with the Sun; being ejected from the Solar System; or colliding with Earth.[85]
eventText: 1% chance that Jupiter's gravity may make Mercury's orbit so eccentric as to collide with Venus; sending the inner Solar System into chaos. Possible scenarios include Mercury colliding with the Sun; being ejected from the Solar System; or colliding with Earth.[85]

eventTitle: Neptune's moon Triton falls through the planet's Roche limit; potentially disintegrating into a planetary ring system similar to Saturn's.[89]
eventText: Neptune's moon Triton falls through the planet's Roche limit; potentially disintegrating into a planetary ring system similar to Saturn's.[89]

eventTitle: "Median point by which the Andromeda Galaxy will have collided with the Milky Way; which will thereafter merge to form a galaxy dubbed ""Milkomeda"".[90] The planets of the Solar System are expected to be relatively unaffected by this collision.[91][92][93]"
eventText: "Median point by which the Andromeda Galaxy will have collided with the Milky Way; which will thereafter merge to form a galaxy dubbed ""Milkomeda"".[90] The planets of the Solar System are expected to be relatively unaffected by this collision.[91][92][93]"

eventTitle: All water currently present in oceans (if not lost earlier) evaporates. The greenhouse effect caused by the massive; water-rich atmosphere; combined with the Sun's luminosity reaching roughly 35â40% above its present value; will result in Earth's surface temperature rising to 1;400Â K (1;130Â Â°C; 2;060Â Â°F); which is hot enough to melt some surface rock.[70][77][86][87] This period in Earth's future is often compared to Venus today; but the temperature is actually around two times the temperature on Venus today; and at this temperature the surface will be partially molten;[88] while Venus probably has a mostly solid surface at present. Venus will also probably drastically heat up at this time as well; most likely being much hotter than Earth will be as it is closer to the Sun.
eventText: All water currently present in oceans (if not lost earlier) evaporates. The greenhouse effect caused by the massive; water-rich atmosphere; combined with the Sun's luminosity reaching roughly 35â40% above its present value; will result in Earth's surface temperature rising to 1;400Â K (1;130Â Â°C; 2;060Â Â°F); which is hot enough to melt some surface rock.[70][77][86][87] This period in Earth's future is often compared to Venus today; but the temperature is actually around two times the temperature on Venus today; and at this temperature the surface will be partially molten;[88] while Venus probably has a mostly solid surface at present. Venus will also probably drastically heat up at this time as well; most likely being much hotter than Earth will be as it is closer to the Sun.

eventTitle: Mars reaches the same solar flux the Earth did when it first formed; 4.5 billion years ago from today.[76]
eventText: Mars reaches the same solar flux the Earth did when it first formed; 4.5 billion years ago from today.[76]

eventTitle: With the hydrogen supply exhausted at its core; the Sun leaves the main sequence and begins to evolve into a red giant.[94]
eventText: With the hydrogen supply exhausted at its core; the Sun leaves the main sequence and begins to evolve into a red giant.[94]

eventTitle: Mars reaches the same solar radiation flux as Earth today; after which it will suffer a similar fate to the Earth as described above.[76]
eventText: Mars reaches the same solar radiation flux as Earth today; after which it will suffer a similar fate to the Earth as described above.[76]

eventTitle: Earth and Mars may become tidally locked with the expanding subgiant Sun.[76]
eventText: Earth and Mars may become tidally locked with the expanding subgiant Sun.[76]

eventTitle: The Earth and Moon are very likely destroyed by falling into the Sun; just before the Sun reaches the tip of its red giant phase and its maximum radius of 256 times the present-day value.[94][note 4] Before the final collision; the Moon possibly spirals below Earth's Roche limit; breaking into a ring of debris; most of which falls to the Earth's surface.[95] During this era; Saturn's moon Titan may reach surface temperatures necessary to support life.[96]
eventText: The Earth and Moon are very likely destroyed by falling into the Sun; just before the Sun reaches the tip of its red giant phase and its maximum radius of 256 times the present-day value.[94][note 4] Before the final collision; the Moon possibly spirals below Earth's Roche limit; breaking into a ring of debris; most of which falls to the Earth's surface.[95] During this era; Saturn's moon Titan may reach surface temperatures necessary to support life.[96]

eventTitle: The widening East African Rift valley is flooded by the Red Sea; causing a new ocean basin to divide the continent of Africa[35] and the African Plate into the newly formed Nubian Plate and the Somali Plate.
eventText: The widening East African Rift valley is flooded by the Red Sea; causing a new ocean basin to divide the continent of Africa[35] and the African Plate into the newly formed Nubian Plate and the Somali Plate.

eventTitle: Estimated time for full recovery of biodiversity after a potential Holocene extinction; if it were on the scale of the five previous major extinction events.[36] Even without a mass extinction; by this time most current species will have disappeared through the background extinction rate; with many clades gradually evolving into new forms.[37]
eventText: Estimated time for full recovery of biodiversity after a potential Holocene extinction; if it were on the scale of the five previous major extinction events.[36] Even without a mass extinction; by this time most current species will have disappeared through the background extinction rate; with many clades gradually evolving into new forms.[37]

eventTitle: According to Christopher R. Scotese; the movement of the San Andreas Fault will cause the Gulf of California to flood into the Central Valley. This will form a new inland sea on the West Coast of North America.[38]
eventText: According to Christopher R. Scotese; the movement of the San Andreas Fault will cause the Gulf of California to flood into the Central Valley. This will form a new inland sea on the West Coast of North America.[38]

eventTitle: Maximum estimated time before the moon Phobos collides with Mars.[39]
eventText: Maximum estimated time before the moon Phobos collides with Mars.[39]

eventTitle: According to Christopher R. Scotese; the movement of the San Andreas Fault will cause the current locations of Los Angeles and San Francisco to merge.[38] The Californian coast will begin to be subducted into the Aleutian Trench.[40] Africa's collision with Eurasia closes the Mediterranean Basin and creates a mountain range similar to the Himalayas.[41] The Appalachian Mountains peaks will largely erode away;[42] weathering at 5.7 Bubnoff units; although topography will actually rise as regional valleys deepen at twice this rate.[43]
eventText: According to Christopher R. Scotese; the movement of the San Andreas Fault will cause the current locations of Los Angeles and San Francisco to merge.[38] The Californian coast will begin to be subducted into the Aleutian Trench.[40] Africa's collision with Eurasia closes the Mediterranean Basin and creates a mountain range similar to the Himalayas.[41] The Appalachian Mountains peaks will largely erode away;[42] weathering at 5.7 Bubnoff units; although topography will actually rise as regional valleys deepen at twice this rate.[43]

eventTitle: The Canadian Rockies will erode away to a plain; assuming a rate of 60 Bubnoff units.[44] The Southern Rockies in the United States are eroding at a somewhat slower rate.[45]
eventText: The Canadian Rockies will erode away to a plain; assuming a rate of 60 Bubnoff units.[44] The Southern Rockies in the United States are eroding at a somewhat slower rate.[45]

eventTitle: "The Big Island will have become the last of the current Hawaiian Islands to sink beneath the surface of the ocean; while a more recently formed chain of ""new Hawaiian Islands"" will then have emerged in their place.[47]"
eventText: "The Big Island will have become the last of the current Hawaiian Islands to sink beneath the surface of the ocean; while a more recently formed chain of ""new Hawaiian Islands"" will then have emerged in their place.[47]"

eventTitle: Cupid and Belinda; moons of Uranus; will likely have collided.[30]
eventText: Cupid and Belinda; moons of Uranus; will likely have collided.[30]

eventTitle: Earth will likely have been hit by an asteroid comparable in size to the one that triggered the KâPg extinction 66 million years ago; assuming it cannot be averted.[48]
eventText: Earth will likely have been hit by an asteroid comparable in size to the one that triggered the KâPg extinction 66 million years ago; assuming it cannot be averted.[48]

eventTitle: According to the Pangaea Proxima Model created by Christopher R. Scotese; a new subduction zone will open in the Atlantic Ocean and the Americas will begin to converge back toward Africa.[38]
eventText: According to the Pangaea Proxima Model created by Christopher R. Scotese; a new subduction zone will open in the Atlantic Ocean and the Americas will begin to converge back toward Africa.[38]

eventTitle: Upper estimate for lifespan of the rings of Saturn in their current state.[49]
eventText: Upper estimate for lifespan of the rings of Saturn in their current state.[49]

eventTitle: The Sun's luminosity has increased by 1%.[50]
eventText: The Sun's luminosity has increased by 1%.[50]

eventTitle: Due to the gradual slowing down of Earth's rotation; a day on Earth will be one hour longer than it is today.[51]
eventText: Due to the gradual slowing down of Earth's rotation; a day on Earth will be one hour longer than it is today.[51]

eventTitle: Estimated time for Earth to naturally replenish its fossil fuel reserves.[46]
eventText: Estimated time for Earth to naturally replenish its fossil fuel reserves.[46]

eventTitle: Prediction of the orbits of the planets is impossible over greater time spans than this; due to the limitations of Lyapunov time.[52]
eventText: Prediction of the orbits of the planets is impossible over greater time spans than this; due to the limitations of Lyapunov time.[52]

eventTitle: From its present position; the Solar System completes one full orbit of the Galactic center.[53]
eventText: From its present position; the Solar System completes one full orbit of the Galactic center.[53]

eventTitle: According to Christopher R. Scotese; due to the northward movement of the West Coast of North America; the coast of California will collide with Alaska.[38]
eventText: According to Christopher R. Scotese; due to the northward movement of the West Coast of North America; the coast of California will collide with Alaska.[38]

eventTitle: Rapid biological evolution may occur due to the formation of a supercontinent; causing lower temperatures and higher oxygen levels.[57]
eventText: Rapid biological evolution may occur due to the formation of a supercontinent; causing lower temperatures and higher oxygen levels.[57]

eventTitle: All the continents on Earth may fuse into a supercontinent. Three potential arrangements of this configuration have been dubbed Amasia; Novopangaea; and Pangaea Ultima.[38][54] This will likely result in a glacial period; lowering sea levels and increasing oxygen levels; further lowering global temperatures.[55][56]
eventText: All the continents on Earth may fuse into a supercontinent. Three potential arrangements of this configuration have been dubbed Amasia; Novopangaea; and Pangaea Ultima.[38][54] This will likely result in a glacial period; lowering sea levels and increasing oxygen levels; further lowering global temperatures.[55][56]

eventTitle: According to the extroversion model; first developed by Paul F. Hoffman; the Pacific Ocean will close completely.[59][60][54]
eventText: According to the extroversion model; first developed by Paul F. Hoffman; the Pacific Ocean will close completely.[59][60][54]

eventTitle: Estimated time for Venus's mantle temperature to reach its maximum. Then; over a period of about 100 million years; major subduction occurs and the crust is recycled.[58]
eventText: Estimated time for Venus's mantle temperature to reach its maximum. Then; over a period of about 100 million years; major subduction occurs and the crust is recycled.[58]

eventTitle: The supercontinent (Pangaea Ultima; Novopangaea; or Amasia) will likely have rifted apart.[54] This will likely result in higher global temperatures; similar to the Cretaceous period.[57]
eventText: The supercontinent (Pangaea Ultima; Novopangaea; or Amasia) will likely have rifted apart.[54] This will likely result in higher global temperatures; similar to the Cretaceous period.[57]

eventTitle: Estimated time until a gamma-ray burst; or massive; hyperenergetic supernova; occurs within 6;500 light-years of Earth; close enough for its rays to affect Earth's ozone layer and potentially trigger a mass extinction; assuming the hypothesis is correct that a previous such explosion triggered the OrdovicianâSilurian extinction event. However; the supernova would have to be precisely oriented relative to Earth to have any negative effect.[61]
eventText: Estimated time until a gamma-ray burst; or massive; hyperenergetic supernova; occurs within 6;500 light-years of Earth; close enough for its rays to affect Earth's ozone layer and potentially trigger a mass extinction; assuming the hypothesis is correct that a previous such explosion triggered the OrdovicianâSilurian extinction event. However; the supernova would have to be precisely oriented relative to Earth to have any negative effect.[61]

eventTitle: The Sun's increasing luminosity begins to disrupt the carbonateâsilicate cycle; higher luminosity increases weathering of surface rocks; which traps carbon dioxide in the ground as carbonate. As water evaporates from the Earth's surface; rocks harden; causing plate tectonics to slow and eventually stop. Without volcanoes to recycle carbon into the Earth's atmosphere; carbon dioxide levels begin to fall.[63] By this time; carbon dioxide levels will fall to the point at which C3 photosynthesis is no longer possible. All plants that utilize C3 photosynthesis (â99 percent of present-day species) will die.[64]
eventText: The Sun's increasing luminosity begins to disrupt the carbonateâsilicate cycle; higher luminosity increases weathering of surface rocks; which traps carbon dioxide in the ground as carbonate. As water evaporates from the Earth's surface; rocks harden; causing plate tectonics to slow and eventually stop. Without volcanoes to recycle carbon into the Earth's atmosphere; carbon dioxide levels begin to fall.[63] By this time; carbon dioxide levels will fall to the point at which C3 photosynthesis is no longer possible. All plants that utilize C3 photosynthesis (â99 percent of present-day species) will die.[64]

eventTitle: Tidal acceleration moves the Moon far enough from Earth that total solar eclipses are no longer possible.[62]
eventText: Tidal acceleration moves the Moon far enough from Earth that total solar eclipses are no longer possible.[62]

eventTitle: The death of most plant life will result in less oxygen in the atmosphere; allowing for more DNA-damaging ultraviolet radiation to reach the surface. The rising temperatures will increase chemical reactions in the atmosphere; further lowering oxygen levels. Flying animals would be better off because of their ability to travel large distances looking for cooler temperatures.[65] Many animals may be driven to the poles or possibly underground. These creatures would become active during the polar night and hibernate during the polar day due to the intense heat and radiation. Much of the land would become a barren desert; and plants and animals would primarily be found in the oceans.[66]
eventText: The death of most plant life will result in less oxygen in the atmosphere; allowing for more DNA-damaging ultraviolet radiation to reach the surface. The rising temperatures will increase chemical reactions in the atmosphere; further lowering oxygen levels. Flying animals would be better off because of their ability to travel large distances looking for cooler temperatures.[65] Many animals may be driven to the poles or possibly underground. These creatures would become active during the polar night and hibernate during the polar day due to the intense heat and radiation. Much of the land would become a barren desert; and plants and animals would primarily be found in the oceans.[66]

eventTitle: Carbon dioxide levels fall to the point at which C4 photosynthesis is no longer possible.[64] Without plant life to recycle oxygen in the atmosphere; free oxygen and the ozone layer will disappear from the atmosphere allowing for intense levels of deadly UV light to reach the surface. In the book The Life and Death of Planet Earth; authors Peter D. Ward and Donald Brownlee stated that some animal life may be able to survive in the oceans. Eventually; however; all multicellular life will die out.[67] The only life left on the Earth after this will be single-celled organisms.

Eventually; however; all multicellular life will die out.[67] The only life left on the Earth after this will be single-celled organisms.
